author: dutchmogul

print_settings.Infill:: 20%, but can increase to improve stiffness.

description.text:
This typing cuff was designed as assistive technology for a person with poor fine motor control in their fingers, and works with capacitance touch screens such as the iPad, iPhone, and Android tablets. It can also be used to type on standard keyboards, phones, calculators, etc. It is printed from conductive PLA. The one I printed is made with Protopasta. There is a conductive foam tip installed in the end to made it more responsive. I used a small piece cut from a fresh, unused ScotchBrite sponge, but any conductive sponge will do. Once the typing cuff is printed, it can be custom sized and bends made by heating it up with a heat gun.
Revision 5 is a thicker version. We had trouble with layer delamination along the length of the stylus, and the finger cuff breaking off, so I made everything a little thicker. I recommend printing with at least 40% infill as well.
For more information on assistive technology, visit http://www.rehabengineer.com, or our agency at http://rehab.alabama.gov/ .

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal

Infill:

20%, but can increase to improve stiffness.

Notes: We found conductive PLA can stick too well to the heated print bed in areas, while in other areas it still lifts off. We have been printing on painters tape to facilitate removal.

Conductive foam and shaping Conductive foam needs to be inserted in the tip in order for it to work well with touch screens. I have found that the blue Scotch-Brite® Non-Scratch Scrub Sponge works very well, so long as it has never been used. Once used, it won't work. Any other conductive sponge will work as well. I cut a piece about 1/4 inch square and an inch long to insert into the tip. After it is installed, I trim it so that about 1/8 inch sticks out of the end.
After installing the sponge, I use a heat gun to shape the cuff, finger cuff, and stylus to the needed shape. It only take a few second to heat the PLA enough to form.

Based on standard typing splint This design is based on the standard typing splints that patients have been using for years. It is modified to work with touch screen devices, and is designed to be easily custom fit to a person, and the stylus can be shaped and bent in what ever way works best for the end user.

comments.text: I am SO excited to try this!  I've been playing around with different models for a cuff stylus but haven't been very successful yet.  I haven't tried heating with a heat gun to re-shape but I've had some success with small modifications using hot water.  I'll post back here when I print!
comments.author: OTin3D

comments.text: So? How'd it go?
comments.author: OTin3D

comments.text: We have made many of these. So long as you heat the plastic thoroughly before forming, it can be bent or shaped without delaminating the stylus.

author: BigFish87

title: MendelMax 2.0: SPDT Switch Plate w/ Guard

description.text:
A switch plate that holds a SPDT switch with a 13mm (1/2") diameter mount. Sits between either the left or right pair of rails on the inside of the machine. I wanted a guard to prevent accidental bumping, and mounting it from the inside means the switch is recessed within the Misumi rails. The guards are spaced wide enough for large hands to tighten the retaining nut.   
Hardware Required: (2) 5mm  t-nuts  and (2) 5mm x 10mm screws. Overall dims: 70mm tall x 55mm wide x 6mm thick.

Printed at 30mm/s with 0.4 infill and 0.300mm layer heights on a MendelMax 2.0 in about 60 minutes. Part weighs approximately 30 grams at 100% infill, so based on a $35 / 1kg filament prices, this part will cost ~ $1.   
In the photos I filled in the text using acrilic paint by hand. Both models (with On/Off Text and No Text) uploaded.

This stylus was designed for people who have difficulty extending a finger to operate a tablet, and have difficulty gripping a standard stylus. It is printed with conductive PLA from Protopasta.
For more information on assistive technology, visit http://www.rehabengineer.com, or our agency at http://rehab.alabama.gov/ .

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

normal

Infill:

10%

Notes: I reduced the infill to make the stylus lighter. I suggest printing on painters tape so the bottom doesn't peel off on the bed when you go to remove the stylus from the print bed.

Conductive Foam You will need to add a piece of conductive foam into the end so that this stylus works better with capacitive touch screen. You can use the foam the IC chips are embedded in, but I have found that a fresh, never used Scotch-Brite® Non-Scratch Scrub Sponge works well as conductive foam. Just cut the scrubby part off, and cut a 1/4" by 1/4" by 1" chunk off the sponge. Once inserted into the stylus, trim the sponge so about 1/8" is sticking out.

Old design, new life. For decades rehabilitation engineers, occupational therapists, teachers, and other allied health professionals have been making modified styli by punching a hole through a tennis or racket ball to make it easier to hold. This updated design uses conductive PLA so that the ball stylus will work with a touch screen.

Animal reports are completely two dimensional and shoe box dioramas are soooo 20th century. Why not take the second grade science standard on describing habitats and spice it up with some 3-D printing?!?
I used Tinkercad with students to design all items due to it's ease of use and since it's browser based it can be used on our school Chromebooks.
CCSS

The beauty of this lesson is that it is not just about learning the basics of 3-D printing, but rather uses desktop fabrication as a means to support students learning about the amazing diversity of animal habitats. Objectives
  • Next Generation Science Standard 2-LS4-1: Make observations of plants and animals to compare the diversity of life in different habitats.
  • With this standard as the driving purpose, your students will also gain knowledge in the process of 3-D design and desktop fabrication by printing habitat scenes.
    • Audience Second grade, with or without experience in 3-D modeling, but this lesson can be modified for any grade level studying habitats, or creating small scenes for display (e.g. book “report” depicting a noteworthy scene, community/historical event, etc). Subject Biology
    Habitats Skills Learned (Standards) CCSS ELA: W.2.7, W.2.8, SL.2.5
    NGSS: 2-LS4-1

• Students begin by making observations (either in person, or through media) of plants and animals in a variety of native habitats, noting key features.
  • Each student (or student group) completes a research report on their habitat, including labeled sketches which are later used when designing the model.
  • Students work independently or with partners to design their habitat models. To decrease the likelihood of frustration, encourage students to consider simplifying their models in the style of Minecraft (an aesthetic many students are familiar with). This approach encourages students to focus less on creating a perfect replica of a habitat, and instead on capturing stylized elements typical of that habitat. If it is decided students lack the modeling experience necessary to complete the project, this step can be performed whole or small group, with the instructor creating the designs based on student input.
  • Habitats are are printed, painted, and displayed alongside student reports. If 3-D printing every habitat model is not an option, screen capture and print their design work on Tinkercad to adorn the cover of their reports.
5 sessions for research and design 5-10 sessions for printing and design modification (depending on the number of printers available)

Students should have an understanding of what defines a habitat, but that could also be part of the lesson if needed. Introduce the basics of Tinkercad whole group, focusing on the user friendliness of the platform, and encourage students to explore and experiment.

Assessment can be dependent on the written report, model design and preparation, and/or brief oral interview to measure learning. I strongly encourage you to display completed models in a prominent area of the school to highlight the learning aspects of 3-D printing and encourage other teachers to follow suit! See the attached Suggested Assessment Guidelines above for more. Handouts & Assets In addition to your school or community library, National Geographic Kids is a great resource for students to begin their research. (http://kids.nationalgeographic.com/)
Here's a Discovery Education lesson that may provide more guidance when implementing this lesson. http://www.discoveryeducation.com/teachers/free-lesson-plans/habitats-of-the-world.cfm

This is a latching hemostat.  It works, but I wouldn't use it for medical purposes. :-)
Offset the handles a bit to unlatch.
It's based on a design by the former ICI Ltd. whose patent has expired.
Makes a handy clamp for small things.  Yet another chip clip?  You could modify it so the jaws close to a fixed opening if you're holding things together for gluing... 
Because of the nature of the plastic (I used ABS) the hinge has a limited life.  I kept flexing one until it broke, about 70 flexes.  When it breaks, print another.

Print & trim.  I added the wings because in earlier attempts the tips and the latch mechanism would curl up off the built platform.  I didn't want to do the amount of trimming a raft would require.
The size is about as large as my Thing-O-Matic can print, about 10 cm (4 inches) long.  It can probably be scaled down some, but keep an eye on the hinge mechanism.  If it gets too thin it probably won't work too well.

description.text:
I liked the original design from bad_ace. But I missed some features on it. New added:
  • Cut out to directly charge the LiPo without opening the Case via USB.
  • Battery dummy connector. No need to solder anithing into the AC-1100 (no loss of warranty and easy to remove.
  • End Cap for the battery case. Now the case can hold LiPo's with PCB protection.
  • Slot for the TP4056 carger.
    • What you need:
  • some wire
  • TP4056 USB Charger around 1,- €
  • 18650 LiPo (I used the 3.000mAh 3.7V version)
  • soldering iron

Printer:

RF1000

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1mm

Infill:

30%

Assembly

  • Battery dummy 2x
    Take some wire and remove the isolation. The wires should be wrapped through the wall to give good contact with the battery. I only wrapped it on one side of each adapter.

  • Drille two holes in the Battery for wireing

  • Add the TP4056 Lipo charger in the slot inside the Battery Pack. (It should fit realy tight)

  • soldere all up and mount it on the back of the Angelcare AC1100

  • The cap can be used if you are using PCB protected LiPo's due to the PCB protection the battery is a little bit to long to fit into the case.

I live with cats. Crafty ones with nothing but time on their hands as they ponder what I am pondering. One of these crafty cats has taught the others how to open bi-fold doors. Ugh... So, while this may be yet another take on the bifold door "lock", this one is mine. :) Two versions. One has a 4mm hole on the "handle" so you can tie a piece of string or ribbon to it. The string is to serve as a visual aid so that guests don't inadvertently pull on a locked door and potentially damage the door and or lock. 37mm width in the channel. Update March 14, 2016
Yeah, print the one with the hole. Took more than one try by more than one person, but the part eventually shattered. :)

After converting my Prusa Mendel to Mecano's Prusa Air2 i wanted to mount my Gen6d electronics out of the way during daily use but still easily accessible if need be. This design utilizes a couple of the existing holes in the Prusa air 2 design. So no drilling required
Simply needs 2 longer ( 6mm longer) M4 bolts to attach to the frame and some standard nylon PCB stand off bushes and screws I've included a version of the plate with PCB stand offs included. May need to drill to suit your screws to prevent the stand offs bursting when tightening the screws. Enjoy
As always comments are welcome If anyone needs an adapted PCB mounting plate to suit other PCBs just let me know via the comments

Basically it is a base with 11 slots that are at pre-determined heights which can all hold the pegs which smoothly slide into them. This can be used to explain how to find the volume of a solid using integration, it can also be used to explain simple geometric properties, etc. 
I have provided both the main body with words and one without them

Objectives This project would allow an instructor(s) to be able to more easily communicate how a 3D object's volume is found through integration. The instructor(s) would also be able to use this model to easily explain other simple geometric properties. Audiences The intended audience for this device is completely dependent on an individual's skill level in mathmatics, it would all depend on the instructor's decision. Preparation Since this is intended to teach students about different geometric properties and how integration works on a 3D object, the more advanced students will need to know the basic principles and rules of integrations, while on the other hand this could be used as an entry level item into a geometry class so the students in this case would need to know very basic geometry skills. Steps Basically the ability of this object leaves the user many options as what and how to operate it.
The basics are the ability to add and remove different pegs in preset heights, this allows for many different examples taht the instructor would be able to create on his/her own. Results The students should have been able to better understand which ever subject matter that their instructor used this apparatus to explain, however this item is entended for the teachings of integrating 3D objects and teaching the basics to 3D objects in geometry.

This is my answer to storing all those failed prints, and raft materials, and leftover filament, in a handy dandy containment unit, called a "Maraca". Make 2 or more and it's PARTY TIME! A great way of celebrating the New Museum, MakerBot, 3D Printing, and the Old with Recycling. Maracas are festive. It requires recycled material in order to fill the maraca. It demonstrates, Reducing, Reusing, and Recycling. Each Maraca requires recycled material (leftover rafts, unfinished prints, and filament purgings) in order to make sound. It is a derivative of traditional maracas, and the New Museum print http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12159 . This design, is a bit bigger, and more hollowed out (in order to be printed with less, while filled with more recycled plastic).

Print the Tops, Print the Handles, fill with recycled 3d Print material (rafts, filament scraps, bad prints), attach the handle with 1/4 turn, and TA-DA! You have a Maraca. Make two per print bed. Print the tops out of White, and bottoms out of other colors. I would chose to make the bottoms out of two or more colors, while preserving the white New Museum look. Be creative, your scrap now has a handy, trendy, new Home. 
If you wish, the top and bottom can be glued together with modeling glue, MEK, or Super Glue.

title: baluster in foam and mold for concrete or plaster

description.text: This foam baluster was cut using Foamcube (a 4-axis cnc hotwire) , once cut you have a positive mold and an instant negative mold you can use to instantly recreate the baluster in concrete, plastic, rubber, plaster or any other cold-pour material. Works great for yards but also looks awesome on stages etc. more information on http://foamcuttingcube.com

The cube can create complex 3D designs in a very simple manner. This time we want to create a mockup baluster for in the garden, and afterwards we also want to have the pouring mold so we can create new balusters very easy and repeatedly in concrete. This is a bracket to attach your extruder on the side of the ultimaker instead of the back.
You will still be able to attach it behind as it was before.
It is also a bit flexible, greatly reducing the extruder noise
You will need to drill 2 small holes in the plywood.
The back plate is a bit overkill but it helps holding the nuts while you assemble.

-print
-drill 2 holes (3,5mm) c-c 45mm in the side of your extruder.
I recommend to add a quick connector in the extruder motor wires (nothing to do with just that mod, but it is good to be able to completely unhook your extruder for transport)
You will need 2x M3x20mm (or M3x15mm) + nuts

description.text: These Headphones should be printed with either 0.1mm-0.2mm layer height, print speeds and other settings are up to you depending on your printer. I am using the new M3D Tough filament for the headband but any flexible filament will work fine.The cups, firewalls and driver mounts need to be printed in a very rigid material to keep flexablility to a minimum. To go over the firewall, you will need to buy some ear pads: http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B011BIIO9I?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=ox_sc_act_title_4&smid=ASSRQ4UOFXJQ4 You will need to use superglue to stick the plain side of the driver mount to the spacers on the firewall after you have put the ear pads on. You will also need 40mm speaker drivers such as: http://www.amazon.co.uk/Inside-Magnet-Electronic-Speaker-Trumpet/dp/B00UJ98EX2/ref=sr_1_2?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1454536611&sr=1-2&keywords=40mm+speaker And a 3.5mm headphone jack such as: http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/9792341056?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=ox_sc_act_title_1&smid=A1LK9W1NQLJGM1 Finally, some really thin wire to connect everything together. Soldering will be involved though just so you know.

I had to design this because I broke my Ubis hot end and decided well, if I'm going to buy a new one might as well upgrade. After I got it is when I realized that it was shorter than the Ubis, much like the E3D hot end. So I whipped this guy up to clamp it under the stepper. this was supposed to be a temporary fix but has worked out well enough that I never got around to changing it. It was only a patch job so that I could print the real parts so I didn't put to much effort into it, however it does not require any modification to the Printrbot stock parts.

Tips on assembly I would recommend that you install the lower extruder arm to the mount before installing the mount to the printer, but it installs mostly the same way the 1405 instructions say to. title: prusa i3 Zonestar p802 Y axis motor mount

description.text:
Y axis motor mount
I have put screw holes in the base to allow attachment to a wooden board.
this should make the motor mount much more rigid than the original mount. I printed this with no infil on the bottom (to save time) and 20% infill.
I would recommend a reasonably thick wall to improve strength round the motor mounting holes, so 1.5-2.1mm this should stop the plastic from crushing when the motor bolts are tightened
it should be printed with the base plate down, and supports only from the bed to the location tabs at the back. the tabs to go into the rear plate are quite a tight fit but should fit snugly. If you have a zonestar printer then I recommend my z axis upgrade. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1205037

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1298757

author: EC6

title: BLTouch Mounting Bracket for Sunhokey Prusa i3

description.text:
This BLTouch mount is designed to be solid, such that the BLTouch will not change position, even under significant stress -- accidental or otherwise.
Mine is printed of ABS, for the higher temperature stability, though I think PLA would be fine too, given the cool air fro the extruder fan.
Holes are such that M3 and M2 self-tapping screws are used. The M2 holes are on the underside, for the BLTouch itself.
Two 3mm holes need to be drilled into the Sunhokey Prusa i3's plexiglass, as you can see from the photo. Simply use the printed bracket as a template for those first, at 2.5mm for the self-tapping screws. Then drill out to 3mm.
The attached CAD file is a Fusion 360 Archive file. Upload to your F360 cloud account and use as desired, according to the CCA licence herein.
Have fun!

comments.text: @walty ... sorry, but I don't use the BL-Touch any more, because I found it wasn't accurate enough, leading to first layer issues. A simple normally-close switch or even micro-switch is an order of magnitude better. In any case, that means I no longer run that configuration, so I don't have the config files for you.

title: UV/vis/fluorimeter cuvette holder with 4 LED slots for irradiation

description.text: A contraption which fits around a standard 1x1 cm (internal) pathlength UV/vis or fluorimeter cuvette. Four LEDs fit around the sides allowing the sample to be irradiated from all four sides while being magnetically stirred from below. Useful for e.g. repeated irradiation/spectrometry cycles in photochemical kinetics measurements. LEDs kept at constant distance from sample: so long as they are well below the liquid level and efficient stirring is maintained, constant and uniform irradiation of the sample can be assumed. The LEDs in the pictures are infrared and were used for infrared photopolymerisation research work. Other wavelengths may of course be substituted: all standard 5 mm LEDs should fit. This was one of my first designs after getting the 3D printer.

author: discostu

description.text:
My Lead Screw Mod for the BQ Prusa Hephestos.
I used a 8mm lead screw called THSL-300-8D which is really common and affordable on eBay and Aliexpress. I also added a new tensioner bracket and endstop for the smooth rods on the motor end in order to enable tensioning of the
belt against the x-axes instead of the z-rod which keeps the smooth rods centered and helps to keep the idler end straight (it was always sitting at an slight angle before for me).
For the tensioner two additional M6 screws are needed ( I used M6x20 but everything above 12mm should be fine )
For the center screw just reuse the original belt tensioner screw. For fixing the brass nut I use eight M3x10 screws. UPDATE: For the sake of completeness I also added a version with the traditional tensioning mechanism. UPDATE: 11/2016
Turns out the tensioner bracket was a bit underdimensioned and tends to bend. I beefed it up quite a bit for v2.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

40%+

Notes: Printed in PLA, works fine.
Without a heated bed you propably need to have a brim or raft.

Imported the STEP from the Hephestos Github into Onshape.
For some reason the bearing diameter on the idler end is way off in the original file, fixed this.

CAD Model The full CAD model is available at Onshape (which is awesome!), I also attached some STEPs.
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/b4f46175ddd6425faebe5b5c Changes in FIrmware In Marlin you have to set the steps / mm setting to 400
(pitch 2mm, 4 starting points thus effectively 8mm per revolution -> 200 steps per revolution * 16 microsteps / 8 mm = 400 steps / mm)
Also you can increase your travel and homing speed considerably.
I use the following:

#define HOMING_FEEDRATE {2000, 2000, 400, 0}
#define HOMING_SLOW_FEEDRATE {1000, 1000, 100, 0}
#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {80, 80, 400,100.47095761381482}
#define DEFAULT_MAX_FEEDRATE {200, 200, 30, 25}

I simply used my old shapes and extruded them as an extruded cut on a rectangular prism. I sketched a rectangle onto one side and extruded cut it down. I added a hole for the axis to go.

Rack/holder for two filament spools/reels. Fits 1 kg spools of the width (ca. 8 cm) and diameter (up to ca. 19 cm) seen in the pictures. The central hole diameter of commercially available spools varies: the thin rollers in the main design file are supposed to be used with cylindrical adapters for various spool central hole diameters. Two of these are supplied as the .STL and .SCAD files: these fit the spools that I have come across and been buying. No guarantee they will fit any others. Designing your own adapter should be easy enough, or you can modify the .SCAD files supplied. Additionally, you will need four 10 mm diameter bearings, some washers and four bolts to screw the bearings into the spool support rollers. It think I used short M3 bolts. The holes will need to be drilled out a bit. It should all be quite self-explanatory looking at the pictures. This design has no provision for preventing filament slipping off the spool and accidentally wrapping around the rollers, potentially causing jams. I haven't had this happen yet but recognise that this is a potential problem. I may come back to this at some point and try and fix it. This was one of my first designs after getting the printer.

RepRap

Printer:

Ormerod 2

Yes

Thinking of Derivative as something that comes out from something else; the use and shape of this key is a derivative of the regular house keys. I wanted to â€œupgradeâ€ this elemental object using the power and precision of 3D printing. There are 3 main aspects this key reinforces or improves on the design conventions: Security:
In the regular process of creating a key the â€œcodingâ€ surface is limited by the production technique. Many times the blade is not complex enough and many locks can be opened by an experienced thief with a pin. In 3D printing there are less limitations and the Coding surface can incorporate more complex shapes, and in a larger area in different axis, making it more complex to copy. Also a 3D key is a key you donâ€™t have to carry around, you can print it only when you need it and even destroy it later, it canÂ´t be stolen, you can upload safely your keys into the cloud, (much safer than real life) Practicality: Keys are normally made of steel, but that is not necessary, keys can be made out of any material as long as the shape of the blade matches perfectly with the wards in the keyway. Imagine the benefits of softer keys; have you ever had any problem with keys at the airport? Have you ever scratched your cell phone with your keys in your pockets? Portability: When was the last time you lost your keys? Do you remember all that search around your house for hours, days, or weeks? Do you remember how expensive was the locksmith? The idea here would be that if you lost your keys you download them from your mail, open the password protected file, and print them right away, before you get late to work.

This is a piece for the contest of NewMuseumChallenge.
But there are simple ways to Re-Key a door knob at instructables.com, try making your own keys and knobs.

comments.text: I think a problem would be that when you use a reprap that isn't perfectly calibrated, or when they key wears down (which would happen more quickly than metal) you'd need to accommodate this into the lock mechanism by increasing the pin height tolerance at which the key would turn. This would make it easier to pick. While this could be countered by drastically increasing the number of pins, this would make for a more expensive lock. The plastic key would wear very quickly against the lock's metal pins too. Really cool idea though, any ideas how you could overcome these things?
comments.author: jamesglanville

comments.text: What if instead of a traditional tumbler lock with pins, you made a lock that integrated a scanner or webcam which looked at the key and compared it with an image of the right key. Is there a way to do this recognition with free software? That would solve the wear problem and if you could define a tolerance band for the key, it would allow some compensation for poorly calibrated machines.
comments.author: jamesglanville

comments.text: if your going into recognition sofware, why not just use an nfc/rfid tag inside the key blade, then as you said no wear and tear, just a slot to stick the key into.
comments.author: MacaroniNgineer

comments.text: Do you have any ideas regarding how you'd make an affordable lock for that key that would be more resistant to attack than the locks that go with the keys that you criticise?

title: The Recursive Observatory: A Derivative of Space and Time

description.text:
3D printing provides not only material synonymy -- in that a single tool can transform a raw material (i.e. a spool of plastic) into endless possibilities -- but most interestingly, it provides this operation repetitively. This repetitiveness affords a very particular quality to form, in that it can vary with time.
The purpose of this exhibit is to inform the audience of this particular quality by providing an instrument that allows the viewer to observe, as an output of the machinery, a 3-D plot representing the flow of the audience viewing the machine (i.e. the thing-o-matic).
The exhibit is comprised of a room with a thing-o-matic within, and a set of sensors (i.e. optical tripwires), organized in a 3-dimensional grid pattern. The sensors capture  material movement through the exhibition space and these inputs are processed and translated into a printable, 3-dimensional form.
The output of the machine represents the 3-dimensional grid of sensors, with spheres, placed at the axial intersections, representing the density of flow -- i.e. how many times the sensors were triggered in a given period of time (r ~ n / t)

The grid of sensors can be cheaply built using a variation of a commonly-known arduino project, the laser tripwire:
http://www.embedds.com/mission-impossible-laser-tripwires-using-an-arduino/
To ensure eye safety, focused, magnified light (i.e. led + lens) can be used instead of lasers. Alternatively, pulsating, low-power lasers can be used (that are not on long enough to be dangerous).

comments.text: 3D printing is not unique in its ability to transform raw material into endless possible objects. Most manufacturing tools can do this. Likewise, all manufacturing tools can create objects repetitively.
comments.author: NickAmes

comments.text: Hi! My original design needs support only for the screw mounts at the top. So what you can do is to set the suport to "touching bed" (in cura). That way the slicer doesnt put support inside the model. It will still put some support in the inlet of the nozzle duct where its not needed but it should be easy to remove with tweezers. And also dont get me wrong im only trying to help.
comments.author: rvjm21

comments.text: unfortunately i am still using the Repetier-Host software, which can be a total pain, especially with support's.
comments.author: rvjm21

comments.text: Actually im using Repetier- host too. Repetier-host has two preinstalled slicers: Slic3r and CuraEngine. You can switch between them under the slicer tab in the second row which has a dropdown-menu with those two slicers. I have used Cura just because i knew more about it at the start than about Slic3r. So im not sure which one is better.

15% fill on all parts except Sun Gear, Ring Gear, & Cover. The Sun Gear should be printed at 100% fill and the Ring Gear & Cover should be printed at 100% (for strength) or 2mm Bottom/Top thickness to keep as flush and strong as possible. You will need 1 of each file, except for the Planetary Gear. You will need 3 of the Planetary Gears. The input is the sun gear (green) and the output is the carrier (red). It was designed so that a 5MM square will fit the sun gear snugly, but not tight and a 5.35 square hole will fit the carrier. Ring gear may require clean up afterwards if you end up with strings across the gears. I found a small file works wonders if any binding occurs while driving the sun gear and holding the casing. The gears are meant to be a very close, but not binding, fit. I included a handle to drive it but anything else can be utilized as well. I will be updating this to include a secondary gear hooked up to the sun to drive it via a worm gear (with the necessary attachments for it). I will be updating in the future to include way to lock the Ring Gear & Cover together (so they won't rotate without manually holding) and also an add-on for a worm gear drive system for further gear reduction. What I found to be Optimal Settings for each Part (with times & PLA lengths)

With such elegant form, this fruit bowl will entice you to take a bite from its sensuous fruits. 
This design offers the opportunity for individuality and creative design in every day-use objects. Sparking the commentary for customization of common elemental objects with a predisposition form which then allows for a more engaging lifestyle through design and self-manufacturing. The form of this particular example is derived from the idea of a net holding fruits together; the solidity of the surface created expands and is varied to retain the different shapes of the fruits as they are placed in the bowl. The physical realization of this and many other objects is achieved through 3D printing, opening the doors for more people to design-build.
Simple making, simple using, simple sharing your design.

title: Meccano Universal Motor Mount max22mm 2 x 6 L Bracket

description.text: 4mm motor mount "slot", allowing up to 22mm gap between centers (if using M3 then 23mm between centres). Central hole = 8mm. Meccano plate = 4mm holes (tight fit), 12.7mm between centres. 1mm wall thickness, 3mm wall height. Wanted to make a universal mount for small 6v/12v motors and geared motors, and also believe Meccano is a great robotics platform... hopefully someone finds this useful :) Most AliExpress motors seem to be 3mm/17mm centres with a 7mm central bearing: so this should fit those, plus be flexible to fit a range of other alternate sizes. Refer my other designs for a specific 3mm/17mm L-bracket This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/l8cR2buKTCT

author: Opium

title: Swimming Pool Hand Rail Clips - Replacement Parts Modeled after a Existing One

description.text:
Replacement clips for a hand rail of a steel wall swimming pool. There are two variations:

  • One with a little hook to hold for example a thermomenter.
I printed it in PLA with a 0.35mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer height, 100% infill, support material and a brim.
